content.description:
In a laboratory population of fruit flies, body color is determined by a single gene with a wild-type allele associated with black body color and a mutant allele associated with yellow body color. A group of researchers hypothesizes that the mutation in fruit flies that causes the yellow body is sex-linked. They also hypothesize that this mutation results in a change in the structure of the sex combs, bristle-like structures on the front legs of male flies that facilitate mating.

To determine the inheritance pattern of the mutant allele, researchers crossed yellow-bodied females with wild-type males. Flies from the <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> generation were then crossed. content.question: Which of the following most likely explains how the sex combs of yellow-bodied flies have a different structure than do the sex combs of wild-type flies?

choices.label: The protein encoded by the mutant body color allele interferes with the development of sex combs.
The protein encoded by the mutant body color allele is only produced if a copy of the wild-type body color allele is present.
The gene associated with body color and the gene associated with sex comb development both exhibit codominance in flies.
The gene associated with body color and the gene associated with sex comb development are located far apart on the same chromosome in flies.

content.answer: The protein encoded by the mutant body color allele interferes with the development of sex combs.
